case_vignette: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath on exertion. He is concerned that he has asthma and would like to be started on albuterol.
question: Which  findings is most likely to indicate a different diagnosis in this patient?
correct_ans: decrease in fev1 by 6% after administration of high-dose methacholine

The case vignette doesn't mention any fatigue, lightheadedness, or fainting.

Final Diagnosis: Based on the information provided, the likely diagnosis is exercise-induced asthma (EIA) or exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB). Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having trouble catching my breath when I do any kind of physical activity for the past three months.
